title: Rebuilding the Altar and Temple
shortSummary: Ezra chapter 3 describes the initial steps taken by the returned exiles to reestablish worship in Jerusalem by rebuilding the altar and laying the foundation of the temple. This chapter highlights the unity of the people, their reverence for God's law, and the mixed emotions experienced as they remember the former temple while celebrating the new beginning.
timeline: c. 538 BC - Early Persian Period, shortly after the decree of Cyrus allowing the Jews to return and rebuild the temple

keyCharacters.name: Jeshua son of Jozadak
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who leads the priests in rebuilding the altar and restoring temple worship.

keyCharacters.name: Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel
keyCharacters.description: The governor of Judah and descendant of David who oversees the rebuilding efforts alongside Jeshua.

keyCharacters.name: Levites
keyCharacters.description: The tribe set apart to assist in temple service and to help with the work of rebuilding the house of the LORD.

definitions.definition: A sacred structure on which burnt offerings and sacrifices were made to God, symbolizing worship and atonement.
A type of sacrifice completely consumed by fire, signifying dedication and atonement to God.
A biblical festival commemorating Israel’s wilderness wanderings, involving dwelling in temporary shelters and offering sacrifices.
A voluntary gift or sacrifice given to God beyond what is required by law, expressing devotion and gratitude.
The initial base upon which the temple building was constructed, symbolizing the renewal of God’s dwelling among His people.

outline.heading: Gathering and Rebuilding the Altar
outline.description: The people unite in Jerusalem and, led by Jeshua and Zerubbabel, rebuild the altar to resume burnt offerings according to the Law of Moses, restoring proper worship and celebrating the appointed feasts.

outline.heading: Preparations for Temple Construction
outline.description: Though the temple foundation is not yet laid, offerings begin; materials and craftsmen are secured, including cedar from Lebanon, authorized by the Persian king Cyrus.

outline.heading: Laying the Temple Foundation
outline.description: In the second year after the return, Zerubbabel, Jeshua, priests, and Levites begin rebuilding the temple foundation, accompanied by joyous praise and thanksgiving to God, following the worship patterns established by King David.

outline.heading: Mixed Emotions Among the People
outline.description: Older priests and Levites who remembered Solomon’s temple weep loudly at the sight of the new foundation, while others shout for joy, reflecting the bittersweet reality of restoration.

application: Commit to corporate worship and unity as the people did when they gathered as one to honor God.
Obey God’s commands in worship and service, following the example of offering sacrifices according to His Word.
Recognize that spiritual restoration often involves both joy and sorrow; trust God’s faithfulness through all seasons.
Support and participate in the work of building God’s kingdom, whether through prayer, service, or provision.

keyVerses.text: Then stood up Jeshua the son of Jozadak, and his brethren the priests, and Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, and his brethren, and builded the altar of the God of Israel, to offer burnt offerings thereon, as it is written in the law of Moses the man of God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the leadership and obedience of God’s people in restoring worship according to His law.

keyVerses.text: And they sang together by course in praising and giving thanks unto the LORD; because he is good, for his mercy endureth for ever toward Israel. And all the people shouted with a great shout, when they praised the LORD, because the foundation of the house of the LORD was laid.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the joy and thanksgiving due to God’s enduring mercy and the significance of rebuilding His house.

keyVerses.text: But many of the priests and Levites and chief of the fathers, who were ancient men, that had seen the first house, when the foundation of this house was laid before their eyes, wept with a loud voice; and many shouted aloud for joy:
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the complex emotions involved in spiritual renewal—honoring the past while embracing the future.
